title: Investigation into Boris Johnson and Jennifer Arcuri paused for police watchdog probe
text:

AN INVESTIGATION into Boris Johnson's relationship with Jennifer Arcuri has been halted while a police watchdog considers opening a criminal case into allegations he may have committed misconduct in public office.

The London Assembly has delayed its investigation into Mr Johnson' relationship with the US businesswoman while Mayor of London, to allow a separate investigation by the Independent Office of Police Conduct to be carried out.

Ms Arcuri is at the centre of allegations that Mr Johnson showed favouritism to help her get hold of £126,000 in public funding and privileged access to three foreign trade missions while he was mayor of London.

After the allegations of impropriety surfaced last month it was announced the IOPC would be investigating any possible misconduct in a public office - but Mr Johnson's team said the referral was a "nakedly political put-up job".

But despite Downing St's objections, the IOPC confirmed it was gathering evidence and had asked for precedence in any investigations to avoid the risk of contaminating evidence or prejudicing potential future cases.

(Image: ITV)

A spokesman said: "We are currently acquiring material as part of our assessment to determine whether it is necessary for this matter to be criminally investigated.

"We have asked the committee to give precedence to our enquiries given we are assessing possible criminality."

The body said it would determine "quickly" if any crime had been committed, but said the timing would depend on how quickly it recieved information from other parties involved.

The news means two of the four probes into the PM’s relationship with the US businesswoman will have been paused while IOPC decides if there is a case against Mr Johnson, after Sadiq Khan announced a probe opened by his office was also on hold.

In a statement, London Assembly Oversight Committee chairman Len Duvall AM said: "The London Assembly respects the IOPC's remit and will not in any way interfere with its important work. However, the Assembly also has an important role and special powers.

"We will consider using those powers immediately following the conclusion of the IOPC's work.

"Subject to that important review by the IOPC, certain people should be on notice that the Assembly may well be knocking on their door sometime soon."

Meanwhile in Parliament Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan has told MPs her department is investigating if Ms Arcuri's Hacker House tech company had any UK-based staff.

The Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport has paused a £100,000 grant to Hacker House after questions were raised about due diligence following reports of her relationship with Mr Johnson/

Mrs Morgan said she had not seen a copy of Hacker House's accounts or seen the initial application made by the US businesswoman.

Asked about checks on whether the company had UK-based employees, she said: "This is all the kind of thing that is part of the review and we said we would publish the review.

"We are looking at all the information we had."

Last week Ms Arcuri refused seven times to deny that the pair’s relationship was sexual but said she hadn't received any special treatment and denies wrongdoing.

“It is really categorically no-one's business what private life we had or didn't have.

"But - and categorically more important - Boris never ever gave me favouritism”

Mr Johnson has previously accused his "old friends" in the Assembly of "barking up the wrong tree" with their investigation and has denied any wrongdoing.
description: The London Assembly is 'pausing' its investigation into Boris Johnson and US businesswoman Jennifer Arcuri, to allow a separate investigation by the IOPC to be carried out
